I know this has nothing to do with cuteness, but I just want to point out that dogs can't be invented so much as discovered by mankind. So, while, yes, we select the ingredients to put in the DNA soup, we haven't invented anything in the way of breeds, they just are what they are, and the factors that make them that way have always been within the dogs already in existence. But, then again, the argument could be made that according to those standards, nothing has ever been invented that didn't already exist, we just made a different recipe..
Which maybe is how we should see the other things in life, too. We don't create, we stir observations together to see what happens. Or maybe the creating does exist, it's just the putting together of ideas, not the putting together of ingredients. 🤷 Idk, y'all spurred to get stirring yet?

Here in Germany, we say "süß" for cute, which translates to "sweet".
So we sometimes make fun jokes, that sound like:
"Es is so süß! Es braucht aber ein wenig Salz" (Btw we have sertain words, that we write with a big A-Z)
That sentence translates to (in english):
"It is so sweet! But it needs some salt"
Why? Because "süß" also means "sweet" for e. g. candys (Chocolate and other sweet stuff).
Yeah... That's all... Now you know German jokes as an English person (probably...)
Also is you want to hear what "Es is so süß! Es braucht aber ein wenig Salz" means, go to google translate, put the input box on "German" or "Deutsch" and paste it in (without the two upper commas).

So to say that if our babies "weren't cute" doesn't necessarily mean that we would find that new thing "cute" but it could likely mean, that humans wouldn't exist at all.

Was watching this with my chiweenie and pitboxer.

I always assumed it was a result of parental instincts kicking in to ensure we wanted to look after and care for cute things

Working at a shelter, I'm surrounded by sheer adorableness all the time. It got me thinking about this when I would see mother cats wirh their kittens, and I wondered if she found her own kittens cute

We know that cats are flooded with endorphins after giving birth to help with the pain, and to make them love their offspring and want to protect them and cherish

But is finding them cute another factor? The mum's often look SO happy with their kittens. They purr when they're allowing them to suckle, when they're grooming their young and snuggling up to nap with them

They wrap their arms around their babies and hold them tight to their bellies where they're close and safe

And of course, they bolt over to their kittens whenever they cry for help. Some mothers are so protective of their kittens, they don't like it when we touch them. But some mums are trusting enough that they know we won't hurt her babies and so let us handle them

So we definitely know cats can love their young, and it makes them happy to see them safe and close by, but do they also find them cute as a triggered instinct to want to nurture?

Cats who aren't pregnant; have been spayed/neutered and never had kittens of their own sometimes adopt kittens, and even tomcats will at times. They're not being flooded wirh the hormones from labour to make them bond with and desire to protect the young, but they still have that desire, so maybe that is the experience of seeing something cute being triggered in cats too

This could explain why dogs are more widely loved than cats. However, what I really find interesting is that “cats” are actually more like people, in that they are independent and will ignore you if they want, whereas dogs are less like people in that they are teachable and submissive.

The very thing we admire “independent expression” in humans, we despise in cats. Is this perhaps because we have a bully instinct that kicks in when a smaller creature dares to defy us, or maybe we simply prefer the heartwarming admiration that a dog shows for us as it ignores our shortcomings... perhaps the greatest of which is that we lack the capacity to overlook the shortcomings of others, like say, cats...

It would seem that the road to becoming more like the dogs we admire, would be to show grace to the cats who exemplify human arrogance... just a thought.

And as always, thanks for reading!

most animals are naturally attracted to babies because of their features
and a sense of innocence. This all relates to survival. If adult
animals didn't find babies cute they wouldn't take proper care of them,
so most species of animals would die out.

Fat, roundness, wide set eyes, small round features are all baby-like,
that's why adults who are considered to have a "baby face" are treated
differently. Most people prefer to interact with others who exhibit
those features. There have been studies conducted on this topic so you
can research if you're interested in knowing more.

I think that the reason we perceive things as cute is connected to survival of species. For example, a baby wolf we will not perceive as a threat and will find it "cute" because it does not pose a threat and be used later in it's life when it has developed enough to hunt (or be hunted) and be a a contributor in the ecosystem. We instinctively want to protect and preserve things that have not yet had the opportunity to be involved in the circle of life so that we can preserve species and in turn keep the ecosystem as stagnant as possible.

Cute is a derivative of acute, as in an acute angle. That is: smallness. Already, it's more than an adult being reminded of their own species's baby, as these proportion differences across age aren't exclusive, yet animals likely don't respond the way we do to cuteness despite this.

Kids can acknowledge cuteness and even babies respond to it their own way as well, be it an animal or cartoon etc., just like any kid can respond to scary images, fangs or not. It's unlikely the functions of baby care are simply taking over at such an age. They can see a smaller, lesser or simpler creature just in general. And everyone can acknowledge that women are smaller and more quaint than the male, which has lead to the words existence in the first place, apparently. She is smaller, like the males of many insects are next to the hawking female.

Did Koko's cat friend merely remind her of her baby, or is it truer she can acknowledge that it is a smaller, more vulnerable creature, like her baby would be. Both incorporate the same features universally and both are soft and quaint on their own, in their own way. Plus, she would probably be more on a scale with the cat itself, as many animal species can bond and grow up together as either play mates or acquaintances.

And so, even if we did look like the mongoloid creature there and were just as smart, we probably would still have a similar appreciation of other smaller creatures too, as they still look nothing like us even now. And that would go on to be one reason why we'd find our own babies cuter then too! It is what we are accustom to and its just "smaller" in general.

I would say that cuteness is at least partially based on visual similarity to our own kind. That is, the animals we tend to find cutest are overwhelmingly mammals (puppies, kittens, and human babies for many), and are therefore like us. As mammals ourselves, we naturally prefer the way a mammal looks over the way, for instance, an arthropod looks (you don't often hear of cute spiders, for instance). Mammals have certain features that we consider 'good', and when we recognise those features in other animals, we like it. And thus, when we recognise that a particular animal doesn't have these features, we don't like it. The more distantly related the animal is to mammals, the less cute we find it.

I wonder if there could also be a psychological phenomenon going on here that's similar to the uncanny valley, but obviously with a different effect. Instead of blurring the line between human and machine, something is blurring the line between human and animal, so when we see certain animals engaging in human behaviours, it's cute.

The question I specifically wanted answering is why we find animals cute. Baby animals in particular. And yes it could be that they possess the same physical attributes as our own babies that we're programmed to find cute for more of an incentive to nurture them, but I think it goes much deeper than that.

As discussed in the video, for something to be physically cute it needs to have a large head/eyes to body ratio and I don't think it's any coincidence that all new-born animals physically look this way. I think every animal has evolved to have cute offspring for multiple beneficial reasons.

One: being cute, as stated before, gives your parents more of an incentive to nurture you.

Two: since cuteness is the same for every animal orphaned babies are likely to be taken care of by exploiting the maternal/paternal instincts of anything that comes across them.

Three: I'm not sure about this one, but I'd have a problem with killing and eating something that I find cute. Maybe that's intentional because killing babies which haven't had the chance to reproduce can threaten the whole species.

For me, there are only certain types of babies I would define as cute. And as someone else stated, I find snakes cute. They have teeny eyes, but they're very far set. For the people saying they don't find babies cute, I'm right there with you. However, you probably still find baby animals and otherwise "cute" things to still be cute like I do, in spite of actual human babies getting no reaction. I believe I've got an explanation for this phenomenon:

The human mind is extremely-focused on social pursuits due to how we evolved, and tries to impose social identifiers and other such constructs on other humans as often as possible. These identifiers range from good ones like "friendly", "harmless" and even "cute", to "annoying", "dangerous" and even "potential threat".

From what I can tell, when looking at something that's "cute", most people have their mental defenses shut off and avoid assessing the glaring negative traits of babies. They don't get as bothered by the sounds and smells, and they don't assess the cute thing's behavior alongside adult human behavioral guidelines. This is very good for humanity, since our being able to see that a baby is highly-detrimental to us now and might potentially grow to usurp us socially and/or physically later makes us want to get rid of the annoyance and/or threat.

In animals that lack this mental inhibitor, like some reptiles and insects, infanticide is frighteningly common. Without having the warm, fuzzy, "gotta protect and nurture this thing" instinct, animals naturally see offspring as tiny, resource-guzzling rivals. And that is what leads to a whole lotta dead babies that weren't fast enough to get away.

I think people who don't find babies cute like myself might have a less-powerful version of this instinct, in comparison to "normal" humans. We more easily see the potential for our own misery and ruin that our offspring carry, and that negates the cuteness quite a bit, if not entirely. We see very clearly that human babies are detrimental and potentially-dangerous, much like the aforementioned insects and reptiles, and thus feel little-to-no biological compulsion to protect and nurture them.

But you may be wondering, "Why wouldn't this apply to baby animals and other cute things too?" The answer to that question is this: Cute things like baby animals do not fall into our social orders and do not possess the same potential for danger as a human, so we don't see them as threats. While we might assess babies as mini-humans, with all of the potential for rivalry and danger of a normal adult human, baby animals and other cute things don't even register on the same scale.

When we look at a cute thing, like a baby animal or a kawaii hammer, we know that it does not even remotely fit into human social order, and cannot really biologically replace us or exceed us among our kin. We also know that, from a physical standpoint, these cute non-human things stand little-to-no chance of hurting/killing us, which deactivates our self-protection guidelines as well.

In a sense, while those of us who hate babies can see their potential social and physical danger to us adult humans, we also see that baby animals/kawaii hammers/etc. are capable of neither.

When we look at a baby bunny or something similarly cute, we intrinsically know that it cannot replace us mentally/physically/socially, and that it poses no physical threat. Therefore, the mental misfire (or perhaps lack of such a misfire) that lets us see babies as threats does not and cannot activate for other cute lifeforms and objects.

While most human beings lump babies and other cute things all together under the "harmless & cute" category, some people instinctively fail to put babies in that category. People like me, and many of you, are these people who do not mentally put babies in the same category as infant animals and cute hammers. We're mentally "glitched" in a sense, seeing everything cute except babies as harmless. 

But hey, that's just my theory on it.

TL;DR: People who hate babies can instinctively see that they might currently or later be threats, so the mental processes judging cuteness go haywire. These people don't have the same problem with animals and/or hammers, because they also instinctively know these things don't pose the same threats as human infants.

Actually, adding one white chocolate would make the WC count 51/101 (because 1 was added to the total), which makes the mix about 50.495% WC, 49.505% DC. Adding a second WC would make the mix 52WC/102Total: 50.980%WC, 49.020%DC. If there were 1 million WC and still 50 DC, the % of DC would be about 0.0000499975%, which is still greater than 0. The % of the dark chocolate would never reach absolute 0 unless all of the DC was removed from the mixture.

From what I know, a brain freeze begins when the nerve endings on the roof of your mouth transfer the feeling of cold to your brain, The thing about those nerves are, they're SUPER sensitive, so they relay that message to the brain strong enough to provide a small headache. That's why putting your tongue on the roof of your mouth stops it. That warms the nerves again, so they no longer send the "cold" message to your brain. Hope that makes sense. :)

A brain freeze is when the roof of your mouth gets cold, and then your brain mistakes that as your brain itself getting to cold, so it rapidly heats itself by mistake, and that is what causes the pain. When you eat something really cold, your body senses this coldness and assumes that your brain is indeed 'freezing'. So your body inundates your brain with warm blood in an attempt to warm it up. The headache is the pain caused by your brain expanding in size due to the influx of extra blood.

A brain freeze is when something cold touches the roof of your mouth enough to freeze the  ends of the veins in your mouth.  As the blood that normal circulates reaches the roof of the mouth from the inside it gets sent back up where it came from instead of circulated.  This raises a red flag in your brain, thus creating a painful feeling.  That is why when you put your tongue to the top of your mouth it rewarms it, allowing the blood to circulate again. :)

Wrong, it's because Youtube counts views beyond 300 slower than likes. When a video hits 300 views, the counter is stopped and Youtube will begin to sort which views are unique and which views are duplicates. Likes continue to be counted as normal because each person can only like once therefore all likes are guaranteed to be unique. This cause s the likes to exceed to views. This is also why the view counter always pauses at ~300. It has nothing to do with the number of subs the channel has.

Most hair in the body at this point in humanity is useless. Eyebrows are meant to keep sweat out of your eyes (seriously) but hair all over the body is pretty meaningless.

The hair follicle for the eyebrow has a shorter grow cycle than follicles on the scalp. 

Eyebrow hair grows for about 4 months, before it falls out and is regrown. 
Scalp hair has a cycle of 2-7 years, stopping at around 80cm. This varies a lot based on diet, health and genetics though.

Is color tangible?

Darkness is quite merely the absence of perceivable light. It isn't composed of anything, because it isn't a thing: it's the lack of a thing.
The reason why we can get black by mixing a colors is because of how pigments work. Green pigments absorb every color except for green, which bounces off and hits your eyes. Red pigments do the same for red, and so on for all pigment colors. So when you mix them all together, EVERY color is being absorbed, so none come out; you get black!
